profiling project which you might have heard of it covers things like um sociological analyses motivation
psychology that sort of thing what hasn't really been done before is trying
to compare behavioral profiles of attackers and that you can use something called case
linkage analysis case linkage analysis is an academic technique predominantly
it's not used that much in the real world and essentially it's trying to link together separate crimes to a
common offender so it's not behavioral profiling or sorry offender profiling offender profiling is looking at a crime
and trying to kind of infer something about the offender who might have committed it based on the features of
the crime case linkage analysis is about taking two crimes and looking at how
similar they are and using that to infer whether or not they were done by the same offender hour regardless of who
that offender might be so it's been used with some success in kind of academic
literature particularly with things like burglary arson robbery homicide that
sort of thing and the example of kind of how granular you get with real-world crimes would be
with burglary for instance you would look at things like entry behaviors so how did the burglar get into the front
door for example or did they get into the front door did they use a crowbar did they use a screwdriver where on the door did they use it then
once they're in the property what sort of property did they take and so on and you would kind of do that for every single possible element of the crime so
you end up with a very very fine grained kind of description of the features of that crime and it's based on case
analysis is based on those same principles of distinctiveness and consistency in a personality psychology
so in terms of applying it to cyberattacks you could for instance log
keystrokes on a honeypot so attackers keystrokes on honeypot take very kind of
granular behaviors from those keystrokes and compare pairs of offenses so every
possible pair of offenses you've got to see whether or not they might have been committed by the same attacker to
determine the degree of similarity there are various things you can do first calculate a similarity coefficient
then do logistic regression and then something called receiver operating characteristic curves and I'll explain
what all of these are in the forensic linguistics part of this talk I didn't go into too much detail around the corner of the map
and the statistics I'll focus on it a bit more in this bit because it's a little bit easier to get to grips with
so in terms of classification what you've got all these keystrokes for instance from a honeypot what you might
do is define some behavioral buckets so you might have navigation behaviors or
enumeration behaviors which loosely tie in to real-world crimes entry behaviors and property stolen behaviors and things
like that you divide those keystrokes into commands and you turn them into yes-or-no questions so you say things
like did the attacker I try to use W get to download malware did they use LS - lah or did they use - la or did they use
- L and so on and so on and you just assign a one if it's a yes and zero if it's a no and you end up with a binary
string for each offense in each of that each of those behavioral buckets you then calculate something called a
similarity coefficient in this case is Jack odds coefficient which is just a very kind of crude measure of similarity
and essentially you calculate three variables the behaviors that are present in both of the attacks you're looking at
behaviors present in attack a but not attack B and then behaviors present in B but I there's no kind of analysis of
joint and non occurrence and you end up you put it through this formula in the top right and you end up with a figure

identical in every feature zero means they're perfectly dissimilar so they're completely opposite essentially you then
put these coefficients into a logistic regression model now if you don't have like a statistics background which I

you run that for each of your behavioral buckets and you end up with a positive or negative correlation there's
something called a p-value which just shows you how a statistically significant the matches and then you can repeat that
with something called forward stepwise logistic regression which is essentially kind of machine learning so you start
off with one domain and you add one at each step and see if it contributes to the power of the predictive power of the
model and if it does you keep it otherwise you discard it now when I say discard important to note that because
we're potentially talking about like evidential stuff it doesn't mean you just throw the data away it's purely talking about the predictive power of
the model and then you can put those regression results into ROC curves and it's just an extra level of kind of
statistical rigor ROC curves basically plot the probability of a false positive
against the probability of a true positive it's just a more reliable measure of predictive accuracy you end
up with something called an area under the curve for an AUC value and now you
